Author: davidw
Content: Interesting, but there's not much substance there, yet.  They release the SDK November 12th.

Author: augustus
Content:
I think the article is pretty accurate though. Mozart could create a symphony in one go but the author does say that he started at age 3. His father encouraged him and then Haydn was also his tutor.

The way I read the article is that intelligence is necessary but is not sufficient in of itself.

Author: sabat
Content:
You have good points, but this article really isn't about Amazon or Google or their recent developments.

This KP guy presumes:

- you need VC to get a startup off the ground

- the end game for all startup people is a $billion+ IPO or buyout

- "web 2.0" has any real meaning.

We all know "web 2.0" doesn't really mean anything in itself: it's just a stamp we're putting on the current state of the web. Unless the whole web is about to die, I think we're OK.

Author: gojomo
Content:
A problem with pmarca's implied 'give writers whatever they ask for and move on' solution is that sometimes legacy royalty arrangements can strangle new-media potential in the crib.

For example, it's my understanding this is what killed the wide republishing of every TV advertisement, as in the early days of the AdCritic.com site. Why wouldn't a company selling something want their TV ads to be as widely seen as possible -- suggesting something like a Creative Commons share-all-you-like license would dominate? But the standard talent contracts from the pre-Internet era required a royalty per showing, which was impossible to collect with open-permission redistribution. Voila -- sites that were only providing free publicity for popular commercials got cease and desist letters, instead of pats on the back.

What I want to know -- Slate explainer, take it away? -- is why the whole industry needs to negotiate a single contract between one cartel of buyers and one cartel of sellers. Why can't different companies and shows try different arrangements, so that talent can vote with their feet (if underpaid) and the widest diversity of novel pay arrangements, that might better enable new-media success, be tried?

Apparently one of the sore spots is that in the last negotiation, writers undervalued future DVD sales -- and DVD income is also a sticking point going forward. Any single master agreement that lasts for years will make the same mistake, in some other area. (Or in DVDs -- whose sales may evaporate as fast as they arrived.)
